title.justification: The title is clearly stated at the beginning and in the header of each page, indicating it as the work being discussed.
title.quote:
Published as a conference paper at ICLR 2023

BROKEN NEURAL SCALING LAWS

extractions.description: The paper introduces 'broken neural scaling laws' (BNSL), a functional form that better predicts and extrapolates the scaling behavior of deep neural networks across a variety of architectures and tasks. The authors assert that BNSL can model non-monotonic behaviors and inflection points, providing more accurate scaling predictions compared to previous models.

type.justification: The paper focuses on empirical evaluation of the predictive power of the proposed broken neural scaling laws across different tasks and architectures.
type.quote: An extensive empirical evaluation demonstrates that BNSL accurately model and extrapolate the scaling behaviors for various architectures and for each of various tasks.

name.justification: The paper discusses scaling laws, a concept that is fundamental to the field of deep learning, and applies it across various deep learning models and tasks.
name.quote: We present a smoothly broken power law functional form (referred to by us as a broken neural scaling law (BNSL)) that accurately models and extrapolates the scaling behaviors of deep neural networks.

name.justification: The entire focus of the paper is on improving the functional forms used to predict the scaling behavior of neural networks, specifically addressing the limitations of existing scaling laws.
name.quote: Our use of BNSLs is inspired by the observation that scaling is not always well predicted by a simple power law; nor are many of the modifications which have been applied in previous works sufficient to capture the qualitative properties of empirical scaling curves.

name.justification: The paper discusses the impact of scaling laws on various aspects critical to training neural networks, such as compute resources, model parameters, and dataset sizes.
name.quote: The amount of compute used for training, number of model parameters, and training dataset size of the most capable artificial neural networks keeps increasing and will probably keep rapidly increasing for the foreseeable future.

name.justification: ViT is mentioned as one of the models used for empirical evaluation in vision tasks.
name.quote: The following architectures of various sizes are pretrained on subsets of JFT-300M (Sun et al., 2017): big-transfer residual neural networks (BiT) (Kolesnikov et al., 2020), MLP mixers (MiX) (Tolstikhin et al., 2021), and vision transformers (ViT) (Dosovitskiy et al., 2020).

is_contributed.justification: ViT is an existing model used in the experiments; it is not introduced in this paper.

is_executed.justification: ViT was run on subsets of the JFT-300M dataset, implying execution in the experiments.
is_executed.quote: The following architectures of various sizes are pretrained on subsets of JFT-300M.

is_compared.justification: The performance of ViT is evaluated against other architectures within the scope of the paper.
is_compared.quote: BNSL yields extrapolations with the lowest RMSLE (Root Mean Squared Logarithmic Error) for 69.44% of tasks.

referenced_paper_title.value: An image is worth 16x16 words: Transformers for image recognition at scale
referenced_paper_title.justification: This is the reference paper for Vision Transformer (ViT).

name.justification: MLP-Mixer is one of the architectures evaluated for extrapolating scaling behavior in vision tasks.
name.quote: The following architectures of various sizes are pretrained on subsets of JFT-300M (Sun et al., 2017): big-transfer residual neural networks (BiT) (Kolesnikov et al., 2020), MLP mixers (MiX) (Tolstikhin et al., 2021), and vision transformers (ViT) (Dosovitskiy et al., 2020).

is_contributed.justification: MLP-Mixer is an existing model used in the paper's experiments.

is_executed.justification: MLP-Mixers were run on subsets of the JFT-300M dataset, implying execution in the experiments.
is_executed.quote: The following architectures of various sizes are pretrained on subsets of JFT-300M.

is_compared.justification: The performance of MLP-Mixer is evaluated against other architectures within the scope of the paper.
is_compared.quote: BNSL yields extrapolations with the lowest RMSLE (Root Mean Squared Logarithmic Error) for 69.44% of tasks.
